name: Ordered pairs in the coordinate plane

skills.name: Describe a point in the second quadrant of a 2D grid by giving its coordinates, where both values are integers
Identify the quadrant that a coordinate lies in
Know how the signs of an ordered pair will change, when it is reflected in one or both of the axes

explanations.A: When reading or plotting coordinates you read from (0,0). Read across first to the left or right and then up or down. Looking at the position of the point, it is at −4 on the x axis. 4 to the left from (0,0)and 2 on the y axis, 2 up from (0,0), giving coordinates of (−4, 2).
explanations.B: It looks like you have read the values in the wrong order.
explanations.C: It looks like you have read the x co-ordinate in the wrong direction, omitting the negative value.
explanations.D: It looks like you have read the values in the wrong order and misread the y co-ordinate as a negative.

explanations.A: Not quite. Coordinates will be in the first quadrant if both numbers are positive. Remember we label the quadrants anticockwise starting from the top right.
explanations.B: Not quite. Remember a negative y-coordinate means we move down instead of up.
explanations.C: The point (-2, -3) is a point 2 left and 3 down from the origin. As quadrants are labelled anticlockwise starting from top right, the point (-2, -3) will be located in quadrant Ⅲ.
explanations.D: Not quite. Remember a negative x-coordinate means we move left instead of right.

explanations.A: The point (4, 5) is 4 units right and 5 units up from the origin. This means to get from (4, 5) to the x-axis (the mirror line) we need to move 5 units down. Reflecting this movement, means we need to move a further 5 units down from the x-axis, to the point (4, -5).
explanations.B: Not quite, I think you reflected in the y-axis. The x-axis (the mirror line) is the horizontal line going through the origin.
explanations.C: Be careful. Reflecting in the x-axis will only change one coordinate. Plot the point on a set of axis. What movement do we need to make to get from the point to the mirror line (the x-axis)? Repeat this on the other side to find the location of the reflected point.
explanations.D: Not quite. Reflecting in the x-axis does not switch the x- and y- coordinates. Plot the point on a set of axis. What movement do we need to make to get from the point to the mirror line (the x-axis)? Repeat this on the other side to find the location of the reflected point.

explanations.A: Not quite. (-1, 4) is in the second quadrant and (1, -4) is in the fourth quadrant. If it was a reflection in the x-axis the new point would be located in the third quadrant. Remember, reflecting in the axes changes the signs on the coordinates. Has the x-coordinate changed sign? Has the y-coordinate changed sign?
explanations.B: Not quite. (-1, 4) is in the second quadrant and (1, -4) is in the fourth quadrant. If it was a reflection in the y-axis the new point would be located in the first quadrant. Remember, reflecting in the axes changes the signs on the coordinates. Has the x-coordinate changed sign? Has the y-coordinate changed sign?
explanations.C: Reflecting in the x-axis changes the sign on the y-coordinate and reflecting in the y-axis changes the sign on the x-coordinate. As both the x- and the y-coordinate have changed sign, this point must have been reflected in both axes.
explanations.D: Not quite. Reflecting in the line y = x switches the x and the y-coordinates over. That has not happened here. Remember, reflecting in the axes changes the signs on the coordinates. Has the x-coordinate changed sign? Has the y-coordinate changed sign?

explanations.A: Not quite. (2, 5) is in the first quadrant and (-2, 5) is in the second quadrant. If it was a reflection in the x-axis the new point would be located in the fourth quadrant. explanations.B: Reflecting in the x-axis changes the sign on the y-coordinate and reflecting in the y-axis changes the sign on the x-coordinate. Comparing the two coordinates we can see that it is the x-coordinate that has changed sign, therefore this point has been reflected in the y-axis.
explanations.C: Not quite. (2, 5) is in the first quadrant and (-2, 5) is in the second quadrant. If it was a reflection in both axes the new point would be located in the third quadrant. Remember, reflecting in the axes changes the signs on the coordinates. Has the x-coordinate changed sign? Has the y-coordinate changed sign?
explanations.D: Not quite. Reflecting in the line y = x switches the x and the y-coordinates over. That has not happened here. Remember, reflecting in the axes changes the signs on the coordinates. Has the x-coordinate changed sign? Has the y-coordinate changed sign?

explanations.A: Almost! If reflecting in the x-axis changes the sign on the y-coordinate, what do you think happens to the x-coordinate when we reflect in the y-axis?
explanations.B: Almost! If reflecting in the y-axis changes the sign on the x-coordinate, what do you think happens to the y-coordinate when we reflect in the x-axis?
explanations.C: Substituting in some values for x and y can help us determine who is correct. If we let x = 2 and y = 3, the point (x, y) becomes (2, 3). (2, 3) is 2 units to the right of the y-axis and 3 units above the x-axis.. This means reflecting in the x-axis will move the point 6 units down, to the point (2, -3), and reflecting it in the y-axis moves it 4 units left, to the point (-2, 3). Comparing these coordinates to the original point, we can see that both Tom and Katie are correct. Reflecting in the x-axis changes the sign on the y-coordinate and reflecting in the y-axis changes the sign on the x-coordinate.
explanations.D: Not quite. At least one of the students is correct. To see who, draw yourself a coordinate grid and reflect some points in the axes. Will reflecting in the x-axis change the sign on the y-coordinate? Will reflecting in the y-axis change the sign on the x-coordinate?

explanations.A: Substituting in some values for x and y can help us determine who is correct. If we let x = 4 and y = 5, the point (x, -y) becomes (4, -5). (4, -5) is 4 units to the right of the y-axis and 5 units below the x-axis. This means reflecting in the x-axis will move the point 10 units up, to the point (4, 5), and reflecting it in the y-axis moves it 8 units left, to the point (-4, -5). Comparing these coordinates to the original point, we can see that only Tom is correct. Reflecting in the x-axis will change the sign of the y-coordinate, making it positive.
explanations.B: Not quite. Reflecting a point in the y-axis does not change the sign on the y-coordinate. For example, the point (4, -5), is 4 units to the right of the y-axis and 5 units below the x-axis. If we reflect it in the y-axis the point will move 8 units left, to become the point (-4, -5). This changed the sign on the x-coordinate. Will reflecting (4, -5) in the x-axis make the y-coordinate positive? Draw yourself a coordinate grid to see.
explanations.C: Not quite. At least one of the students is incorrect. To see who, draw yourself a coordinate grid, plot some points with negative y-coordinates, and reflect them in the axes. Will reflecting in the x-axis make the y-coordinate positive? Will reflecting in the y-axis make the x-coordinate positive?
explanations.D: Not quite. At least one of the students is correct. To see who, draw yourself a coordinate grid, plot some points with negative y-coordinates, and reflect them in the axes. Will reflecting in the x-axis make the y-coordinate positive? Will reflecting in the y-axis make the x-coordinate positive?
